title-group.article-title: Palliative Medicine: Looking to the future

p.italic: Knowledge is of two kinds. We know a subject ourselves, or we know where we can find information on it.

disp-quote.p: Samuel Johnson, quoted in Boswell’s Life of Johnson

body.p: What is the purpose of Palliative Medicine? Our concern as an editorial team is to publish articles that make Palliative Medicine a destination of choice for readers to, as Samuel Johnson says, ‘find information’ about palliative care that is robust and relevant. The reason for this editorial is to highlight to you, our authors, reviewers and readers, how we are evolving to meet your needs in changing clinical, and research, publishing and dissemination environments.

The overarching purpose of the journal has changed little since its inception in 1987 and is probably best articulated in the way we position the journal in our instructions to authors:
Palliative Medicine is a scholarly research journal dedicated to improving knowledge and clinical practice in the palliative care of patients with far advanced disease. It reflects the multi-disciplinary and multi-professional approach that is the hallmark of effective palliative care. Papers are selected for publication based on their scientific excellence, contribution to knowledge, and their importance to contemporary palliative care. We welcome papers relating to palliative care clinical practice, policy, theory and methodological knowledge.

As we evolve, we have no intention of amending this purpose; it serves us well. It highlights what we feel are the key features of this journal: a focus on high-quality research, contemporary clinical utility and broad perspectives. Perhaps, the only aspect not explicitly encapsulated in this statement is our international focus and a desire to publish research that has wide-ranging relevance across the globe. We try to meet this purpose in the best way we can, reflecting the many changes that have occurred within palliative care in the last 25 years. We highlight below three areas of development in management, strategy and processes.

sec.title: New Editorial Board and Editorial Advisory Board
sec.p: We are delighted to warmly welcome two new members, Dr Nathan Cherny and Dr Jenny van der Steen, who are joining our Editorial Board and Dr Henrik Støvring who has already joined as our statistical editor. Dr Cherny is Norman Levan Chair of Humanistic Medicine and Director of Cancer Pain and Palliative Medicine, Department of Oncology, Shaare Zedek Medical Center, Jerusalem, Israel. He also chairs the European Society of Medical Oncology Palliative Care Working Group. He brings wide-ranging international expertise in palliative care within oncology to the journal. Dr van der Steen works at the EMGO+ Institute for Health and Care Research, one of the interfaculty research institutes of the VU University Medical Centre Amsterdam and the VU University Amsterdam. She brings epidemiological expertise, with particular interests in dementia- and nursing-home care. We have also created the position of statistical editor, a new departure for the journal. Dr Støvring works at the Department of Public Health – Institute of Biostatistics at the University of Aarhus, Denmark. We look forward to the new perspectives and insights these new board members bring to the journal, together with our refreshed Editorial Advisory Board. We have appointed a number of new editorial advisory board members to reflect the changing nature of palliative care globally. The full details are on our website at http://pmj.sagepub.com/. Thank you to all editors and board members past, present and future, but particularly to Dr Nicholas Christakis and Dr Franco De Conno who are standing down from the board.

sec.title: New ways of making your work visible
sec.p: We choose to publish the highest possible quality of research relevant to the palliative care field that is submitted to us. We know that many of the articles we publish are highly cited and well downloaded, and we use that as the best proxy we have for relevance to our readers. It is fair to say we were disappointed with this year’s slight dip in our impact factor, but with a journal of this size and scope recognise that just a few very highly cited articles leaving the impact factor window can make this difference.

What we have changed, which we hope will make a real impact on the visibility, citations and downloads of the future, is a clear strategy to improve the visibility of the articles we publish, so that they are easy to search for and find. This work starts with our authors, as we actively review titles, abstracts and keywords with them. Our abstracts are now structured, so that the key information readers need is quickly retrievable, and we pay equal attention to appropriate titles and keywords. Our aim is that however readers choose to search the literature they will find relevant research published in Palliative Medicine.

We also have an active social media presence on Twitter @palliativemedj and Facebook. We encourage you to interact with us using these media, and we post daily updates on the research we publish. We also contribute regularly to the EAPC blog (http://eapcnet.wordpress.com/), with authors of selected articles discussing their work; this blog is freely available on the EAPC website.

sec.title: New ways of meeting the needs of authors, reviewers and readers
sec.p: We want to encourage you to submit your highest quality research that is likely to have a major impact on palliative care practice, policy or theory to us. We know that we have to provide you with the best possible service to encourage new, and retain existing, authors. We have therefore set ourselves new deadlines for our decision-making processes to improve the turnaround time for submitted manuscripts. We are also starting to run regular special editions starting from next year. Forthcoming special editions will focus on family carers and the palliative care of those with non-malignant disease, and we are still inviting submissions for these (see our website for more details). We will be working more closely with reviewers to support them in their work and are planning to run a reviewer workshop in 2013.

We look forward to continuing to meet the needs of the palliative care community and, as ever, are delighted to enter into dialogue with our authors, reviewers and readers about how we can best do this.
